body: Don't hesitate to push here the stuff you're want to see working up to Saturday morning.

Some cases that would be nice to see:
- Ok, Google, what is a HashMap (or whatever)?
  - Some fancy response like ("Ok, Alexey, you're supposed to know what a HashMap is") would be super-cool
- Go to the _assignment_ of the field 'X'
  - Here we'd need to maintain context (that we're inside some method of class that has field named 'X', etc., that'd Yaroslav shining moment)
[SDK Docs](http://www.jetbrains.org/intellij/sdk/docs/reference_guide/messaging_infrastructure.html) are not much help here. Need to intercept menu opening actions to swap an appropriate grammar #6.
That NPE happens because plugin libraries are loaded with different classloader (|'ve had a nasty workaround hack on getting TTSService, but I've forget to add a comment there)
@breandan fixed now, see Idear#initTTSService
Oh yeah!!! It will be great, instead of googling and browser opening we could request google for it and show quick doc!!! Nice!!
Yeah, that should work.
Nice! Thanks for solving that one.
cf. [Configuration Management for Sphinx-4](http://cmusphinx.sourceforge.net/doc/sphinx4/edu/cmu/sphinx/util/props/doc-files/ConfigurationManagement.html).

Another bad hack incoming. Since Sphinx4 doesn't allow us to access the utterance data directly, we dump the .wav files to disk, then fire a REST request to get the speech result. Finally, we need a way to open a URL in the browser.
- http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23159506/saving-utterance-to-audio-file-with-sphinx4
- https://sourceforge.net/p/cmusphinx/discussion/sphinx4/thread/50b9aa29/

Does that mean that we're un-recoverably broken on Windows. 
I mean, that `CustomMicrophone` doesn't diverge that much from `Microphone`.

It looks like if we could debug something and fix a simple bug, using only voice commands that'll be great. 

I think fixing some NPE by adding not null check anywhere will fit.

Seems like a lot of work though, but possible.

So we need to:
- set exception breakpoint
- locate to problem
- surround it with not null check
- run all this stuff again to ensure everything works
What are your thoughts on this?
Are we capable to run configurations already?

Can now, but only selected one.
So we could preselect one, or if will be time, implement it appropriately.

I'll try to hack breakpoints for now

It's not as much a problem with our implementation as `Microphone`. Whenever the user says "ok idea", an `IllegalStateException` gets thrown. CMUSphinx is working on [a patch](https://sourceforge.net/p/cmusphinx/bugs/412/).
I suppose the fix for this is to recompile CMUSphinx when the next version is released.

According to Nikolay Shmyrev, 

> It's more important to properly process recognition result, allow user to correct input and provide fast response time. It is more important to be able to analyze lattice results than 1-best.
> 
> Hard-coded changes like grammar switch can only confuse user and the recognizer... It's recommended to have grammars as relaxed as possible, not as tight as possible.

cf. https://sourceforge.net/p/cmusphinx/discussion/help/thread/9c84d504/

Hi @mbait! 

Wit.ai looks awesome!

Nevertheless it pulls us go online, which doesn't seem as a particular drawback, though impedes it as  a self-contained solution.

I agree. The idea is to use offline recognition wherever possible and only call a service when the user clearly intends to do so (ie. Google an error or exception). Privacy aside, I think it would be much more interesting to try and decode speech offline anyway. We're not going to learn anything by calling an API (although I'm sure it's a fine product).
hi. is there a patch for this available @breandan ?
Hi @jskye, there is not yet a fix for Windows.
ok thanks for the reply. this only blocks the use of two LiveSpeechRecogniser's at once correct?
Yes, this issue should not affect most commands, but it will crash when you say, "okay google". I have not discovered a successful workaround.

Hi Erik, do you have the latest version of the [Kotlin Plugin](https://plugins.jetbrains.com/plugin/6954) enabled? I could be mistaken, but that should be the only requirement.

edit: Just saw you have the Kotlin plugin. Let me try installing it from scratch. From what I remember, you may need to add the libraries in [idear/lib](https://github.com/breandan/idear/tree/master/lib) to your dependencies manually.

I think so, I'm using the bundled version of IntelliJ 15. (see screenshot) 1) I checked out the repo, 2) changed the project SDK to IDEA IC-139.224.1 (Java 8), and that's it. Maybe step two is incorrect? I can find the IntelliJ classes, but just not the Kotlin ones, and I see no option to add it. Creating a new project with Kotlin support is no problem.

Hmm, that's unusual. It should automatically detect the Kotlin classes when your IDE loads the project. I was able to successfully build the project on a clean install of IntelliJ IDEA CE 143.382. When first launching the IDE, I added a JDK, and the _IntelliJ Platform Plugin SDK_ (as described in the [SDK Docs](http://www.jetbrains.org/intellij/sdk/docs/basics/getting_started/setting_up_environment.html)), then it was able to detect the Kotlin files and build the project with no further configuration required.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/175716/11200539/ec583612-8ca4-11e5-8b0d-dd378dbfa581.png)

There must be some reason why it does not detect the Kotlin files in your project, however you can still try to force IntelliJ IDEA to recognize them. What happens when you select **Tools | Kotlin | Configure Kotlin in Project**?

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/175716/11200621/9045322a-8ca5-11e5-9f28-26842aa90ecd.png)

I recently untracked the `idear/.idea/workspace.xml` file, but when the project is sucessfully configured, that file should contain a section that [looks like this](https://github.com/breandan/idear/commit/51aa4f53348d625c789c07dc65e155d788aca436#diff-18ce661d1fc3d790f60910ad9c3c5192L728). If all else fails, you could try pasting it into your `.idea/workspace.xml` file directly, but normally we don't recommend editing the `.idea/*` files directly as they can easily become corrupted.

```
<configuration default="true" type="JetRunConfigurationType" factoryName="Kotlin">
  <extension name="coverage" enabled="false" merge="false" sample_coverage="true" runner="idea" />
  <option name="MAIN_CLASS_NAME" />
  <option name="VM_PARAMETERS" />
  <option name="PROGRAM_PARAMETERS" />
  <option name="WORKING_DIRECTORY" />
  <option name="ALTERNATIVE_JRE_PATH_ENABLED" value="false" />
  <option name="ALTERNATIVE_JRE_PATH" />
  <option name="PASS_PARENT_ENVS" value="true" />
  <module name="idear" />
  <envs />
  <method />
</configuration>
```

edit: When IntelliJ IDEA CE first loads the project, I can see the following popup:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/175716/11200972/09ba805e-8ca8-11e5-91ad-c3ed356ed2d1.png)

After clicking Configure 'idear' module in 'idear' project as Kotlin (Java) module, the following dialog appears: 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/175716/11201002/3bbeae18-8ca8-11e5-99a0-b6b6501cbeaf.png)

After generating the compiler bundle, it placed a few files under `idear/lib`, which I have checked into git, under 1d31f794d9cace238da01de276e99b7e456418d9. Please let me know if it's still giving you trouble.

Ah, yes, there it is! If I do `Tools -> Kotlin -> Configure Kotlin`, then it fixes most of the issues; now the Kotlin code is found.

However, there is still one issue left now, and that is that the code doesn't compile. I think I know why that is. This is caused by the AceJumpAction:

```
Error:(35, 13) Kotlin: Class 'AceJumpAction' must be declared abstract or implement abstract base class member public abstract fun actionPerformed(@org.jetbrains.annotations.NotNull p0: com.intellij.openapi.actionSystem.AnActionEvent): kotlin.Unit defined in com.intellij.openapi.project.DumbAwareAction
```

So, I guess this code doesn't work with IntelliJ 14, but only with 15?

Based on your prior screenshot, it looks like we're on the same version of the Kotlin plugin, which means we're also using the same compiler. It might be an issue with IntelliJ IDEA 14*, but in theory it shouldn't matter which version of IntelliJ IDEA you are using, as long as it uses the same compiler.

*Have you applied for an [Open Source license](https://www.jetbrains.com/buy/opensource/?product=idea) to IntelliJ IDEA 15? Surely you must be eligible...
